title: Worked Solution
text:
For the iodine anion in question, we can determine the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons as follows:

$$1$$. Protons: The atomic number of iodine (I) is $$53$$, which means it has $$53$$ protons.

$$2$$. Neutrons: The mass number is given as $$127$$. The number of neutrons can be found by subtracting the atomic number from the mass number:

Number of neutrons $$=$$ $$127$$ - $$53$$ $$=$$ $$74$$

So, there are $$74$$ neutrons.

$$3$$. Electrons: Since this is an iodine anion (I⁻), it has gained one extra electron. Normally, a neutral iodine atom has $$53$$ electrons (equal to the number of protons). With the extra electron, the total number of electrons in the I⁻ anion is:

Number of electrons $$=$$ $$53$$ + $$1$$ $$=$$ $$54$$

Thus, one iodine anion (I⁻) has:
- $$53$$ protons,
- $$74$$ neutrons, and
- $$54$$ electrons.
